newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Luxembourg growth to accelerate in 1997, 1998 - OECD.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg growth to accelerate in 1997, 1998 - OECD.

text.p: Luxembourg's economy will accelerate in 1997 and 1998, while jobs growth remains robust and consumer price inflation averages around two percent, the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development said.

In a semi-annual report released on Thursday the Paris-based think tank forecast Gross Domestic Product (GDP) at market prices would grow by more than three percent in both 1997 and 1998 versus a 2.4 percent increase in 1996.

Exports were expected to remain buoyant, reflecting the economic upturn in neighbouring countries and a more competitive steel industry. As a result, the contribution of foreign trade to growth was likely to become positive again.
On the domestic front, gross fixed investment should remain the most dynamic component of total demand, it said.
But the growth of private consumption may pick up only moderately, in line with the evolution of real wages.

Employment growth was projected to accelerate but as most new jobs would probably be filled with cross-border workers the unemployment rate may decline only slowly to slightly less than three percent in 1998, the report said..
The general government budget was likely to remain in surplus.
The main risks to the projections were a weaker than expected recovery in continental Europe which would "significantly depress" economic activity in Luxembourg, especially in the steel industry.
Note - contributions to changes in real GDP (as a percent of real GDP in the previous period).
